summary: study was performed using nasopharyngeal/oropharyngeal swabs collected during the H1N1 pandemic influenza. the IFITM3 rs12252 was genotyped by RFLP and tested for association with hospitalization. most people infected with influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 virus experienced mild disease, with upper respiratory illness similar to seasonal influenza virus infection. gastrointestinal symptoms occurred more frequently in patients infected with pandemic influenza virus than in those with seasonal influenza. animal models seem to support the biologic plausibility of a genetic susceptibility to influenza A virus. it has been shown that an interferon inducible transmembrane 3 protein (IFITM3) profoundly alters the course of influenza virus infection in a knockout mouse model. recent studies suggest a close association between the IFITM3 rs12252 variant (C allele) and influenza severity infection. s12252 variant (C allele) and risk of hospitalization due to respiratory illness in portugal patients with influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 infection. case-control genetic association study comparing frequency of IFITM3 rs12252 variant between hospitalized influenza-like illness (ILI) patients (cases) and non hospitalized ILI patients (controls) was performed. ILI negative patients were ILI patients who were swabbed and tested negative for the Influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 virus. all included patients were selected from the INSA cases. the following exclusion criteria were used to perform the selection. nasopharyngeal/oropharyngeal swabs were collected into a suitable transport medium for preservation of virus, molecular diagnostic and virus culture. real-time reverse transcriptase PCR methodologies and platforms were used for laboratory diagnosis. ele and the originated fragments were visualized on a 2% agarose gel. Statistical analysis was performed using the R program [18]. P-values0.05 were considered statistically significant. 62089 ILI cases were reported to the laboratory network during the H1N1 pandemic. 7780 influenza A(H1N1)pdm09 positive cases were identified at INSA 16376 samples for Influenza diagnosis. patients for whom the time lapse between the symptoms onset and the sample collection was over 7 days, to avoid misclassification due to low viral load of the sample collected. 312 hospitalized patients were identified after the exclusion criteria application. hospitalization was used as a measure of disease severity. additional diagnoses, viral isolation, antigenic and genetic characterization of viral isolates were performed according to the procedures previously described [15].
